webTitle: Walmart to be prosecuted for firing striking workers, union group says

fields.standfirst: Our Walmart says National Labor Relations Board will demand action against Walmart for illegally firing and disciplining workers
fields.body:
The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), the federal agency that oversees workers' rights, is to announce decision to prosecute Walmart for firing, discipling and threatening workers who went on strike or attempted to unionise, according to the group organising the strikes.

Our Walmart, a union-backed group, said the NLRB will prosecute the company for illegally firing and disciplining 117 workers, including some who went on strike in June. The board's decision will also include threats by managers and spokespeople aimed at discouraging them from striking, Our Walmart said.

Workers would potentially be awarded backpay, reinstatement of their positions and the reversal of disciplinary actions, Our Walmart said.

Our Walmart said it has filed more than 100 unfair labour practice charges against Walmart with the NLRB, including 20 illegal terminations and 80 disciplinary actions. The board said in September that it was looking into "several cases".

The alleged terminations and disciplinary actions relate to a demonstration in June by more than 100 workers who travelled to Bentonville, Arkansas, to take part in a rally at Walmart's shareholders meeting, according to OURWalmart. The threats relate to a statement by David Tovar, a Walmart spokesman, who said on CBS News that "there could be consequences" if employees did not report to work.

Workers have a legally protected right to protest.

Walmart said it would contest the decision by the NLRB. It said in a statement: “We disagree with this position by the Division of Advice. This is just a procedural step and we will pursue our options to defend the company because we believe our actions were legal and justified.

“The fact is, we provide good jobs and unparalleled opportunities for our associates. This is our busiest time of the year and we're focused on serving our customers and helping them have a great holiday season.”

webTitle: Co-op Group plans overhaul after allegations about chairman

fields.standfirst: Management orders review into 'any inappropriate behaviour' after allegations Paul Flowers bought cocaine and crystal meth
fields.body:
The Co-operative Group of supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies faces a radical overhaul after its new management ordered "a root and branch review" of the organisation following allegations that Paul Flowers, former chairman of its bank, had bought cocaine and crystal meth.

The group, which can trace its roots back 170 years to the Rochdale pioneers, has also started "a fact-finding process to look into any inappropriate behaviour" as a result of the claims about the 63-year-old Methodist minister, who has apologised for his "stupid and wrong" behaviour.

Already suspended by the church for three weeks, Flowers was also suspended from the Labour party, which he joined aged 16. He has previously been part of a finance and industry group set up by Labour leader Ed Miliband.

A video obtained by the Mail on Sunday showing Flowers counting out £300 after being asked for "money for the coke" also sparked calls by Conservative MP Andrew Tyrie for the current system of authorising top bankers to be overhauled.

The Co-op Group, which has been forced to hand over ownership of 70% of the bank as it scrambles to plug a £1.5bn capital shortfall, did not say how long its review into the organisation would take to complete. But the internal investigation is getting under way at a time when it has already admitted it may have to review its donations to the Labour party and bring in fresh blood from outside the Co-operative movement.

Referring to the reports about Flowers, the group said: "Given the serious and wide-ranging nature of recent allegations, the new executive management team has started a fact-finding process to look into any inappropriate behaviour at the Co-operative Group or the Co-operative Bank and to take action as necessary."

It said a review of the "democratic structure of the organisation" was needed, and added: "We need to modernise to ensure that the interests of all our 7 million members are properly and directly represented in the oversight of our business activities."

The group's board is run by 20 members of the movement and its current chairman, Len Wardle, a former university fellow, has already said he will leave at the annual meeting in May.

Wardle has already recommended that his successor is appointed from outside the co-operative membership as part of an overhaul of the structure.

Other changes have already taken place. The chief executive, Euan Sutherland, who took the helm in May, was appointed from B&Q to replace Peter Marks, who had been with the Co-op for 45 years. However, Sutherland does not have a seat on the board of the group, which employs 100,000 people but has been driven to a loss by the problems at the bank.

There was no further detail about what "inappropriate behaviour" might have taken place either at the bank – which Flowers chaired from 2010 until his resignation in June – or in the wider Co-op Group.

The Methodist church, which had issued a statement of behalf of Flowers when the allegations emerged on Sunday, had no further comment. West Yorkshire police had already said an investigation had been opened.

The Mail on Sunday reported that Stuart Davies, a friend of Flowers, had handed over the footage and text messages, which appear to have been sent after Flowers had appeared before the Treasury select committee of MPs on 6 November. In one message Flowers allegedly wrote: "I was 'grilled' by the Treasury select committee yesterday and afterwards came to Manchester to get wasted with friends."

Tyrie, who chairs the select committee, used the latest allegations to push for regulatory reforms. He also chaired the parliamentary commission on banking standards, which had called for an overhaul of the current regime for approving bankers to hold top jobs and replacing it with a licensing system.

"The 'approved persons regime' degenerated into little more than a bureaucratic box-ticking exercise. Its shortcomings were already manifest nearly four years ago," said Tyrie, urging the government to implement the recommendations of the commission.

"It is crucial that this opportunity is now seized. It would be a disaster were we to lapse back into the bad habits of old," said Tyrie.

Labour said Flowers' membership was being suspended "for bringing the party into disrepute". Miliband said: "He was involved in the Co-op and that is no longer the case. I think we will leave it there. You appoint people from a whole range of backgrounds to look at a whole range of issues and we have a range of business people working with us."

The select committee will take evidence on Tuesday from David Anderson, boss of the Co-op Bank when it merged with Britannia Building Society in 2009, and could yet call Andrew Bailey, deputy governor of the Bank of England and head of the Prudential Regulation Authority.

Conservative MP Mark Garnier, who sits on the committee, told Reuters: "I think it's absolutely vital we get the regulator back because of the questions that are being asked, so rightly. What the hell was going on to make the regulator approve this guy? How did that happen?"

webTitle: FTSE moves higher after Dow record, while Sainsbury lifted by buy note

fields.standfirst: Analysts at Shore Capital put supermarket on buy list for first time in four years
fields.body:
With US markets hitting new peaks, the FTSE 100 started the week on a positive note.

The index finished 30.02 points higher at 6723.46, as investors continued to be buoyed by the prospect of the US Federal Reserve maintaining its economic stimulus programme. There was also optimism that China's recently announced economic reforms could support global growth.

Among the risers J. Sainsbury added 2.5p to 411.5p as Shore Capital raised its recommendation from hold to buy. This is the first time the broker has put Sainsbury on its buy list for four years. Analysts Darren Shirley and Clive Black said:

Sainsbury's interim results were ahead of Shore Capital and market expectations, driven by a stronger-than-expected margin performance. After a meeting with finance director John Rogers, we upgrade our pretax profit forecast by around 1% to £807m, earnings per share of 33.2p, year-on-year growth of 9.5%.
Sainsbury is undoubtedly the most robust of the mainstream UK grocers, outperforming at the revenue and margin lines. Whilst the broader grocery market remains challenging, with volumes under pressure and likely to remain so for the foreseeable future, we believe such concerns are already well baked into expectations for Sainsbury, with the potential for any profit surprise on the up rather than downside. In the current elevated equity market, we believe a 2014 PE of 12.3 times, and enterprise value/EBITDA multiple of 7.4 times, represents good value for a stock expected to deliver around 14% total shareholder return, driven by 9.5% earnings per share growth and a 4.4% dividend yield (1.9 times covered), and so we upgrade our recommendation to buy.

Aberdeen Asset Management was the best performer in the FTSE 100, up 62.9p or nearly 15% to 489.7p after its long awaited purchase of fund management group Scottish Widows from Lloyds Banking Group, 0.79p better at 76.17p.

Aberdeen is issuing 132m new shares to Lloyds to pay an initial £560m, giving the banking group a 9.9% stake in the company. It will also pay another £100m in cash depending on performance.

Elsewhere Royal Bank of Scotland rose 3.3p to 333.3p after saying it was in talks to sell its retail investor products and equity derivatives business.

British Airways owner International Airlines Group dipped 0.2p to 362p despite Nomura issuing a buy note and raising its price target from 335p to 380p following the airline's investor day on Friday.

A profit warning from Petrofac saw the energy services group slump nearly 17%, down 239p to £12.

The company said it expected net income to be flat or modestly ahead next year, reflecting delays at a number of contracts including the Upper Zakum project in Abu Dhabi and the Berantai project in Malaysia. The company was also more cautious on its 2015 targets.

It said it was still aiming to double its 2010 net income of $431m by 2015, but this now depended on the timing of various contracts.

Outsourcing group Capita lost 6p to 977p after the surprise news that its chief executive is to quit after 26 years. Paul Pindar, who joined from 3i, will leave next year to go back to working in private equity. He will be replaced by deputy chief executive Andy Parker.

Among the mid-caps, Aveva, whose software is used to design power plants, shipping and energy facilities, dropped 201p to £23.65, the worst performer in the FTSE 250, following a disappointing update. The headline figures showed an 11% increase in half year revenues to £108.5m and a 6% rise in profits to £27.3m, but within that, its enterprise solutions division showed a slower than expected 5% revenue rise.

The company blamed a Latin American shipyard customer running into serious financial difficulties, and a major oil and gas group abandoning an information management project. Aveva added that the market was still evolving so sales cycles were hard to predict.

Finally Aim-listed China New Energy saw its shares nearly double, up 2.275p to 4.75p. The company, which designs factories and develops technology to convert non traditional feed into fuel, unveiled contracts with two Hungarian businesses to build ethanol plants worth around £60m over the next four years. This follows a memorandum of understanding signed at the end of last month to develop a biorefinery in Nigeria.

webTitle: Questions were already being asked about Paul Flowers's credentials | Jill Treanor

fields.standfirst: The former Co-op Bank chairman's Treasury select committee appearance demonstrated his difficulty in grasping numbers
fields.body:
Even before the weekend's allegations that the former chairman of the Co-operative Bank had been filmed buying illegal drugs, questions were being asked about the suitability of Paul Flowers to oversee a bank with 4.7 million customers.

His appearance at the Treasury select committee had instantly demonstrated his difficulty in grasping numbers when he told MPs the bank had assets of £3bn. The correct figure was £47bn. Little wonder that it prompted Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the committee, to argue that bank chairmen needed experience in the financial services industry.

But it also sparked further questions about the sorry saga at the Co-op Bank, now in the throes of a £1.5bn rescue under which its current owner - the group of supermarkets, pharmacies and funeral homes – will cede a 70% stake to bondholders led by two US hedge funds.

For instance, why did the Co-op Group believe Flowers was a suitable chairman? A methodist minister who had worked for a bank for four years after leaving school in the late 1960s, he told MPs he had been on a shortlist of four before his appointment in March 2010.

It was, he said, part of the Co-op Group's ethos to appoint "a democrat from within its own numbers" to chair the bank. The decision to pick him was unanimous, according to Flowers, who pointed out that he was picked because the bank was, after all, owned by a co-operative organisation.

This sparks another question: what process did the City regulator of the day, the Financial Services Authority, go through to approve his appointment? According to the BBC some members of the Co-op were disappointed that Flowers got through the FSA selection process, which in itself is a shocking admission, appearing to demonstrate the mutual's lack of process in recruiting a chairman in the first place. Flowers clearly took comfort from the fact he had been approved by the regulator yet could not remember who sat on the five-member interviewing panel at the FSA. It turns out that he did not have a formal interview at this stage but had been interviewed formally the previous year when he became a non-executive.

It is perhaps something of a surprise that the regulator did not give him a formal interview to become chairman in 2010 but he did have a fireside chat with Graeme Hardie, an adviser to the FSA, and Clive Adamson, who is still head of supervision at the new regulator. The regulator took some steps to counter his lack of banking knowledge – he had years of experience on sitting on boards – by demanding he appoint two deputy chairs.

Then there is the matter of how the Co-op Bank ended up spending two years attempting to buy the 631 branches from bailed out Lloyds Banking Group, particularly as the FSA would have needed to approve the transaction.

The Treasury is keen to assert that there was no political interference in this deal but Flowers himself noted that there was plenty of cheerleading from the sidelines. After all, why would Mark Hoban, the Conservative MP who was City minister at the time, have taken part in 30 meetings in an effort to facilitate what became an ill-fated deal?

Even the details of how that deal came to fail are far from clear. The £1.5bn capital shortfall now being plugged with the help of US hedge funds was only made public after the branches deal had collapsed and ratings agency Moody's downgraded Co-op to junk status. Why did this capital hole take so long to materialise? Was it because the new banking regulator, the Prudential Regulation Authority, decided to get tough and impose new standards?

The Co-op has admitted the regulators are looking at disclosures it made in its annual report about its capital position, although the Financial Conduct Authority has not yet offered an opinion on this topic.

The FCA – which has taken over many of the FSA's responsibilities – should be conducting a full-blown investigation into what went wrong at the Co-op Bank and how the regulators and politicians handled it. The Treasury has the power to order it to do so and should demand one the moment the current fundraising is completed. If nothing else, Paul Flowers's indiscretions have given the Co-op story a new prominence and finally, yesterday, sparked the mutual into a "root and branch" review of its organisation. It is an opportunity that should not be wasted to overhaul the 170-year-old organisation.

webTitle: BMI boss warns of problems facing private healthcare business

fields.standfirst: Company makes £57m profit but Stephen Collier says its finances are stretched by interest and rental costs
fields.body:
Stephen Collier, boss of hospital group BMI, has warned of a "clear and immediate concern" facing the indebted private healthcare business, which is battling to persuade competition regulators it is not making excessive profits.

Despite revealing on Monday that top line operating profits for the year to September of £57m, up from £50m a year earlier, much of that sum was wiped out by £40m of maintenance and other capital expenditure costs as well as close to £10m of recurring interest bills on the group's borrowings.

The looming crisis facing the group could have a serious impact on the NHS, which last year accounted for 33% of BMI's caseload, up from 29% for 2012.

Together with rivals Spire and HCA, BMI has been targeted in provisional findings by the Competition Commission, with regulators indicating they intend to enforce a sell-off of up to 20 hospital sites.

In September, the Guardian revealed the regulators were expected to revise down the disposal target to about 13, with an enforced sale of 10 sites likely to be imposed on BMI.

The commission has been unsympathetic to BMI's stretched finances because its calculations do not make allowances for businesses which take on heavy borrowings or rental commitments.

"If the profits you make are wiped out by [onerous interest or rental costs] that doesn't remove the competition problem," one official said.

Collier submitted his response to the commission earlier this month and will sit down with the regulator in a private meeting next Monday to further lay out his concerns.

"We continue to assess the potential impact of the proposed remedies … and we are very concerned about the significant detrimental impact they could have on patients and healthcare delivery in the UK."

webTitle: Reality check: Obamacare is not to blame for Walmart's sluggish sales | Heidi Moore

fields.standfirst: Corporations love using Obamacare as a scapegoat for poor performance, even though the numbers don't support that at all
fields.body:
While Obamacare is a catastrophe for the White House, it's the gift that will keep on giving all holiday season for the executive suites of American corporations.

Obamacare is, after all, the perfect scapegoat. Large, unwieldy, already a failure so pathetically at odds with its goals that the President himself has had to apologize repeatedly. Obamacare is, for the moment, the 90-pound weakling of domestic policy, so it's not surprising it has attracted the attention of bullies looking to kick more sand in its face.

That's how you get the nation's largest retailer, Walmart, blaming Obamacare in part for its disappointing financial performance. Walmart's CEO said dip in same-store sales was attributable to consumers worried about the tsunami of healthcare bills facing Americans. The Wall Street Journal reported that True Value, a private company, also blamed Obamacare for bringing financial troubles to the economy.

Here's why Walmart's attack on Obamacare – and any other company's – is ridiculous. Walmart has about 140 million customers a week in the US, and 245 million customers a week globally.

A tiny, tiny fraction of that – roughly 130,000 people, nationwide – have signed up for Obamacare. In fact, the number of people who have signed up for Obamacare is but a small fraction of Walmart's own workforce, which numbers 2.2 million people.

Even if every single person on Obamacare stopped shopping, Walmart would still serve more than 139.8 million customers a week. Obamacare isn't even a blip within that. It's a rounding error.

The thing is, this search for a financial scapegoat is a pattern, the kind of fantasist imagining best dreamed up while the corporate jet – of which Walmart has 19 – sits idle on the tarmac.

Walmart, once a Wall Street darling, has spent all year exuding excuses for its disappointing financial performance in the same way that an isotope of uranium emits radiation. In January, Walmart's bete noire was the payroll tax. In June, it was government uncertainty. In the fall, it was cuts to food stamps. This week, it's Obamacare.

Two things Walmart has reliably avoided mentioning: that rivals like Costco and Family Dollar have been doing pretty well all year, which undermines all the conspiracy theories, and that Walmart has been struggling with its own divisive labor issues. One of those labor issues – its infamously low pay – has led some Walmart stories to start a food drive, asking workers to donate food to their own colleagues.

When Walmart is implicitly acknowledging that its wages won't let people afford one good dinner, its financial issues are way beyond Obamacare. But, while you can in fact blame Walmart for trying to pin its troubles on Obamacare, it's far from the first. Earlier this year, a kind of mass hysteria hit a number of companies, including most recently David's Bridal, as they used Obamacare as an excuse for laying off employees or moving them to part-time work.

Needless to say, that doesn't hold up either: if there's a business need for workers, businesses will keep them on. The number of part-time workers is not growing significantly enough to provide proof that such a mass corporate protest is having an impact, even if the corporate idea of "impact" is to devastate an already struggling economy.

In addition, the bigger question there is why employers feel entitled to employ people, often at low wages, without providing healthcare for them. Is the idea that when they get sick or die, they'll be replaced like lab rats? That's a pretty diseased view of how capitalism should work.

The "blame Obamacare" meme has one origin, and it's not the economic impact of one new, modestly sized policy. Instead, there's an underlying streak of smugness that overtakes corporate executives after enough big bonus checks and trips on the private jet: they start to believe that success is in their control, while failure is due to evil outside forces. When companies are earning a lot of money, it's because they're smarter and better. If they're facing rough times, it's because someone – usually the government – is thwarting the purity of capitalism.

It's all bunk, of course. Nearly all the roadlocks put up by government – taxes, gridlock, policy failures – are easily hurdled by today's megacorporations. Government also provides enormous practical subsidies – in agriculture or for minimum wage workers – that somehow corporations never seem to complain about. Those companies have also reaped rewards from the stock market, which is hitting new highs regularly and is up 26% this year, despite the weakness of the economy.

It all goes to show that the high end of the economy has truly become about the haves and have-nots: those who make excuses, and those who have better sense than to try. The latter are in very short supply.

webTitle: One in six Walmart factories in Bangladesh fail safety review

fields.standfirst: Company publishes list of factories subject to independent inspection, but workers' groups say reports are vague
fields.body:
One in six clothing factories used by Walmart in Bangladesh failed to meet basic standards of structural, fire or electrical safety, the US retailer has found.

Independent inspections for the company – which owns Asda in the UK – found that 32 of its 200 factories required urgent work to fix serious failings, including one factory that was so unsafe it had to be shut down and another with an illegal eighth floor containing the staff canteen.

Most of those factories have since carried out remedial work, but production is still temporarily halted at two factories, which have failed to make the improvements required for basic safety since the inspections started in May.

The inspections were carried out after the Rana Plaza disaster in April, when more than 1,100 workers died and many more were injured after a factory collapsed.

The problems emerged as Walmart published a list of 75 of the 200 factories that had been inspected and rated on electrical and building safety, from A, which would be a model factory, to D, the worst level.

The paperwork did not give details of the problems at each factory, but Jay Jorgensen, the company's global compliance officer, said the worst problems included the factory with an additional floor and another with an extra building that it did not have paperwork for.

Walmart had promised to publish a list of the factories it had inspected in June, but Jorgensen said the process had been delayed by civil unrest and difficulties in sourcing sufficient new materials, such as fire doors.

Jorgensen said Walmart had published the list in order to help other companies sourcing in the country, including the 100-plus signatories to an international factory improvement deal, the accord on fire and building safety in Bangladesh (AFBSB), which Walmart has refused to sign up to.

He said that 65% of the factories used by Walmart were also used by signatories of the accord, and added: "We want to collaborate with the accord."

Workers' rights campaigners slammed the reports as too vague to be helpful. Theresa Haas, of the US-based Worker Rights Consortium, said: "Walmart's reports are superficial at best. They contain no detailed information whatsoever about the results of the inspections or the remediation that has supposedly been carried out and there is no mention of the need to inform workers about risks that have been identified in their workplace.

"Walmart's approach to factory safety has not changed and the company continues to rely on a model that has repeatedly failed to protect workers from fire and building safety disasters."

Meanwhile, Jenny Holdcroft, policy director of the international union IndustriALL, called on Walmart to formally sign the accord. "I honestly don't know what anyone could do with the information they have published," Holdcroft said. She said the accord would be publishing full details of its inspections, which are due to start imminently. She said without proper knowledge of the issues raised by inspectors, workers could unknowingly find themselves working in unsafe conditions.

Jorgensen said Walmart had appointed a permanent team of 10 inspectors who would continue to work with factories, including making a further assessment in January. "We are committed to the welfare over the long haul," he said.

Walmart said that the factory inspections had been carried out over a period of several months by teams of six to 12 inspectors and cost $4m. Some of the money was used to provide training for workers in workplace safety.

A fund provided by the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety, a group of North American retailers that have fought shy of signing the legally underpinned AFBSB, has helped support workers during factory closures while work was carried out. There are also low-cost loans available through the alliance to help factories make building improvements, but none of those identified by Walmart has taken up that offer.

webTitle: Liv Garfield joins small team of women running blue chip businesses

fields.bodyText: The "one in, one out" game of count the female bosses running blue chip British businesses continued on Monday when BT Group's Liv Garfield was unveiled as the new boss of the water company Severn Trent. Garfield, 38, who has been responsible for the £2.5bn rollout of super-fast fibre broadband as boss of BT's Openreach division, will singlehandedly boost the number of women leading FTSE 100 companies by 25% when she takes up the role in spring 2014. Currently, there are just three other women running FTSE 100 companies: Carolyn McCall at easyJet, Angela Ahrendts at Burberry and Alison Cooper at Imperial Tobacco. A fourth will almost certainly join their ranks next month as newly-privatised Royal Mail, run by Canadian Moya Greene, joins the FTSE 100. However, Ahrendts is quitting Burberry in mid-2014 to join Apple, and is to be replaced by Christopher Bailey. Yorkshire-born Garfield – whose pay and bonus package at Severn Trent could reach £2.4m a year – has built a strong reputation in business circles, serving as a non-executive director at Tesco and being named in September as one of the top 10 young high-flyers in Fortune Magazine's annual 40 under 40 list – making her the highest ranking Brit in the league table. Her appointment to run Severn Trent comes two and half years after Lord Davies set a goal for a quarter of the seats in the boardrooms of the UK's 100 largest firms to be held by women by 2015. At the time, women held 12.5% of the positions and there were 21 all-male boards, so FTSE boardrooms now being 19% female -– with just five all male boards – looks like a triumph. Most of the gains, though, have been achieved by companies hiring part-time non-executive directors – the area that Germany is now attempting to address via legislation – rather than full time executives such as Garfield. However, Helena Morrissey, the boss of City fund manager Newton Investment Management and founder of the 30% Club, which campaigns to bring more women onto boards, said quotas such as that proposed in Germany were not welcome: "[Germany's move] is disappointing, unhelpful and unnecessary. Meaningful, sustainable change requires voluntary, business-led action. The sharp pick-up in the pace of change in the UK over the past three years shows that progress can and will be made once business leaders see this as mainstream to their success." The proportion of full-time female executive directors in FTSE 100 companies has reached just 6.1% – up from 5.5% when Davies set out his targets, partly because every addition seems to come just as another women drops off the list. When McCall, a former chief executive of Guardian Media Group, became a FTSE boss on the elevation of easyJet to the bluechip index earlier this year, her appointment came just as two other women – Dame Marjorie Scardino of Pearson and Cynthia Carroll of Anglo American – had just announced they were stepping down from their roles.

webTitle: Lloyds takes 10% stake in Aberdeen Assets

fields.standfirst: Decision to sell to a Scottish competitor cements Edinburgh's place as one of the world's top fund management hubs
fields.body:
Taxpayer-backed Lloyds Banking Group has agreed to take an almost 10% stake in Aberdeen Asset Management in exchange for transferring the investment arm of Scottish Widows to the fund manager.

The cash and shares deal, which values Scottish Widows Investment Partnership at close to £660m, transforms Aberdeen into the biggest listed fund management group in Europe, with assets under management of about £340bn – two-thirds more than prior to the sale.

The deal comes little over a decade after Aberdeen saw its name tarnished after the group found itself at the centre of the 2002 controversy over split capital trusts.

Lloyds' Scottish Widows life assurance, pensions and investments business will remain part of the bank. However, policyholders' funds will be managed on behalf of Lloyds by the enlarged Aberdeen business.

While Aberdeen founder Martin Gilbert hinted that small job losses were expected, the acquisition was motivated by growth ambitions.

Lloyds decision to sell to a Scottish competitor, rather than a rival such as Australia's Macquarie, cements Edinburgh's place as one of the world's top fund management hubs.

As consideration for the sale, Lloyds agreed to take £560m in new Aberdeen shares, equivalent to 9.9%, with a further £100m contingent on the future success of the business.

Last night shares in Lloyds, which is still 33% owned by the UK taxpayer, closed up 0.79p at 76.17p.

Shares in Aberdeen closed up 62.9p at 489.7p, despite the dilutive issue of new capital. The group also posted strong results yesterday, with a 39% rise in underlying pretax profits.

webTitle: Dow Jones hits 16,000 points as stock markets hail China's reforms - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
Beijing's plans to liberalise Chinese economy sends world stock markets to highest level since January 2008
• Dow hits record high
• German DAX closes at record high
• Details: How Shanghai and Hong Kong markets jumped overnight
• Bitcoin soars to $600
fields.body:
5.58pm GMT

And finally....

Over on Wall Street - the Dow Jones has dropped back from its record high but is still clinging above the 16,000 mark.

It's currently up 39 points at 16,006, a gain of 0.28%, and on track for a new closing high (although there's still three hours trading to go).

Boeing remains the leading stock, up 2% after announcing plenty of new deals at the Dubai Airshow. As in Europe, banking shares are also up - with JP Morgan gaining 1.8% and Goldman Sachs up 1.6%.

Here's our news story on the Dow's latest rally: Dow Jones industrial average crosses 16,000 for first time

And that's a good moment to stop for the evening here in London. Back tomorrow for more. Until then, goodnight and thanks (as ever) for the comments. GW 

5.41pm GMT

Here's David Jones of IG's closing market report:

European markets

It has been yet another positive session for European markets, with the German DAX hitting fresh all-time highs. The FTSE has had a more cautious start, but found its feet as the morning went on and soared through the 6700 level. However, the UK blue-chip index is still lagging behind some of its continental and US equivalents.

The FTSE is still around 1.5% below the May highs, whereas the S&P500 and DAX are 7% above their equivalent levels. The relative under-performances by the mining sector and financials have caused some drag for the FTSE in recent months, but if US strength continues it can surely only be a matter of time before the UK index sets fresh highs for the year.

US markets

Another day, another all-time high for the Dow Jones. The opening on Wall Street saw the Dow push through the 16,000 level, giving a year-to-date performance of 22%.

These are impressive gains by any normal measure, and it can be tempting to feel that a top cannot be too far away. Many fingers have been burnt this year trying to predict that major turning point. But for now at least, with an accommodative central bank, it appears that investors are more afraid of missing out on gains than of losing in any immediate downturn.

Some would see this sort of psychology as warning enough that the enthusiasm is starting to get out of hand.

5.40pm GMT

European stock markets close higher

It's all over in Europe's stock markets, where the main indices have all risen on the back of the China rally.

The German DAX is the stand-out performer, closing at a new record high as the new 'risk-on' mentality sparked by Beijing's plans sent shares up across the region. Peripheral bank stocks performed well, leading the risers in Milan and Madrid.

Here's how it finished:

  • FTSE 100: up 30 points at 6723, +0.45%
  • German DAX: up 56 points at 9225, +0.6%
  • French CAC: up 28 points at 4320, +0.66%
  • Italian FTSE MIB: up 418 points at 19,105. +2.2%
  • Spanish IBEX: up 87 points at 9,783, +0.9%

The rally began softly enough, after shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai had rallied over 2%. But it gathered pace through the day, helped by the prospect of continued stimulus measures from the Federal Reserve.

The gold price, meanwhile, is down around 1% - confirming that investors were less fearful today.

Reaction to follow....

5.29pm GMT

Back in Spain, King Juan Carlos's decision to scupper his own yacht in solidarity with those suffering from the financial crisis has rather backfired.

From Barcelona, Stephen Burgen reported:

King Juan Carlos' gesture of frugality earlier this year when he renounced his yacht has backfired after a court ruled that the crew were owed €1.2m (£1m) in payment for illegal dismissal.

The money will come from the Patrimonio Nacional, Spain's equivalent of the civil list. In short, the taxpayer will foot the bill.

The 41.6-metre (137ft) yacht, called Fortuna, was moored in Mallorca and cost €21m. It was a gift from a consortium of businessmen in the Balearic islands, each of whom contributed €600,000.

Now that the king has renounced the yacht, they plan to recoup some of their outlay by selling the vessel.

More here, including details of the captain's not-inconsiderable salary: 

Spanish taxpayers pay price as king goes from have-yacht to have-not

5.07pm GMT

Bloomberg; Caution over Chinese economic plans

As I explained back at 8am GMT, China's government is proposing a raft of economic reforms, following last week's party meeting.

The plan would see its financial sector more liberalised - giving the markets more control over interest rates and the cost of water, and energy supplies. There would be new property rights for farmers, and an easing of restrictions on where people can work.

Beijing is also proposing a shakeup of how state-owned firms are run, and also wants to encourage partnerships between private firms and public ones.

Just the kind of initiatives to please the stock markets, in fact. But there's one serious caveat that might have been downplayed -- these are proposals, not new policies ready to be implemented. 

There's good analysis on this over on Bloomberg: China’s Bold, Contradictory Reform

Here'a a flavour:

The plan calls for results by 2020. Putting the ideas into effect will involve every level of government and multiple layers of China’s labyrinthine bureaucracy. Liberalization threatens vested interests and will be met with resistance. Good results are by no means guaranteed.

Another reason to withhold judgment is that the party statement undoubtedly envisions a more market-based economy -- yet not what one might call a normal country with a normal system of government. Its statement is rife with the contradictions that flow from this.

The Communist Party frowns on what it calls contradictions, and it constantly dedicates itself to eliminating them more boldly -- but the anomalies it has in mind are labor disputes, street protests and “emergencies on the Internet.” The jarring tensions between state and liberty, state and market, and one-party rule and democracy are barely noted in the document, much less confronted or resolved.

Updated at 5.08pm GMT

4.30pm GMT

Camilla Sutton, chief currency strategist at Scotiabank in Toronto, confirms that China's latest economic reform plans are pushing shares up in many markets.

She said:

Risk appetite is strong... after details of China's reform prove more dramatic than expected, suggesting a focus on market liberalization and reforms in both the government role and the broader corporate structure.

(via Reuters)

4.08pm GMT

The US dollar has lost ground against the euro today, dropping 0.2%, meaning €1 is now worth $1.3526.

Again, the prospect of the Federal Reserve maintaining the flow of easy money is driving market sentiment.

Here's more from Christopher Vecchio of DailyFX: 

The US Dollar continues to edge lower in the days after Federal Reserve Chairwoman nominee Janet Yellen’s Senate testimony on Thursday, as the soon-to-be most powerful woman in the world made clear her intentions to keep monetary policy as loose as possible in the near-term.

4.04pm GMT

US investors have got one eye on the upcoming release of the minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest monetary policy meeting, on Wednesday afternoon.

Those minutes will show how many Fed committee members see a case for tapering (cutting) its $85bn/month QE programme, and how many want to leave it alone for some time.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets doesn't expect much new clarity, saying:

Despite the focus on the latest minutes it remains quite likely that they won’t tell us too much that we don’t already know given Janet Yellen’s comments last week. It might be more prudent to study the comments of the various FOMC members due to speak this week, including Dudley and Plosser later today, Evans tomorrow and James Bullard on Wednesday and Thursday of this week. 

Stocks in focus include Boeing after the confirmation of 250 orders for its new 777 airliner at the Dubai air show with Emirates and Etihad the main buyers.

3.55pm GMT

Howard Marks, chairman ofOaktree Capital and an influential investor, isn't too impressed by the breathless reporting about the US stock indices hitting various round numbers. It means not a jot, he points out on Bloomberg TV.

These numbers have no significance.... They do attract attention, but they don't mean anything.

So what should we be thinking about?

On a price/earnings measure (ie, what it costs to buy shares in US companies compared to the amount of money they're making), shares are up around 50% since 2011. That has brought P/E ratios back to around their historic post-war average.

So, as Marks puts it, "if you think they [those P/E averages] are still relevant, it means you think the market's reasonably priced".

And that's the 16,000 point question. In a world where economic growth has been scarcer recently, and where central banks will be keen to tighten monetary policy if the good times return, companies may face some tall hurdles in the years ahead... 

Marks says he believes US growth will be a little faster in 2014 than this year, but it don't reach levels where people actually feel wealthier.

3.20pm GMT

Here's a graph showing how the Dow Jones industrial average has risen by around a quarter in the last 12 months:

It's been a pretty steady rise, apart from a couple of wobbles since the summer. They were usually prompted by the prospect of central banks tightening monetary policy. The punchbowl of easy money has had it usual effect, and it's not being taken away quite yet.

3.13pm GMT

Boeing is the biggest riser on the Dow Jones index, up almost 3% after it reported a $76bn deal to sell 150 777 mini-jumbos to the Emirates airline.

Updated at 3.13pm GMT

3.10pm GMT

If it feels like the US stock markets are hitting new record highs every few days, then you're right.

Scarlet Fu, chief markets correspondent for Bloomberg Television, reports that one in every four trading days in 2013 has seen a new record high on the Dow Jones or the S&P 500 (or both).

The Dow is up 22% so far this year. 

2.46pm GMT

What goes up....

2.42pm GMT

Dow hits 16,000 for first time ever

The Dow Jones industrial average has hit a new record high, jumping over the 16,000 points mark for the first time ever, at the start of trading on Wall Street.

The Dow rose 61 points in early trading to hit 16,023, up 0.4%. The S&P 500 is also hitting new highs, up 2.48 points to 1,800.66.

This is driving global stock markets their highest level in at least five years (the MSCI index of world shares hit its highest level since January 2008 this morning).

Traders on Wall Street are reacting to speculation that the Federal Reserve will continue its $85bn/month stimulus programme for several months, before starting to wind it down (or taper it)

Christopher Vecchio of Daily FX attributes the rally to incoming Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen. Last week, she told the Senate banking committee last week that the US economic recovery needed to be supported by the Fed. 

The rally in China's markets overnight, and in Europe today (details here) are also helping to push shares higher.

Updated at 2.46pm GMT

2.25pm GMT

Our old friend Bitcoin is romping higher today too. The virtual currency hit $600, just a fortnight after crunching through the $300 mark (live price here).

The twists and turn of Bitcoin remain quite a mystery (to this bear of little brain, anyway), but it appears there may be a solid news hook to today's rally.

The US Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs is due to hold a hearing on the implications of Bitcoin on law enforcement (following the arrest of Ross Ulbricht, accused of running the Silk Road online drugs marketplace).

As Marketwatch explains, the FBI has told the committee that it has an open mind on Bitcoin: 

“The FBI’s approach to virtual currencies is guided by a recognition that online-payment systems, both centralized and decentralized, offer legitimate financial services,” Peter Kadzik, principal deputy assistant attorney general, wrote in a letter on Sunday.

“Like any financial service, virtual currency system of either type can be exploited by malicious actors, but centralized and decentralized online-payment systems can vary significantly in the types and degrees of illicit financial risk they pose.”

There's also speculation that stronger demand from China is pushing the price up (see City AM for more details).

The usual caveat applies, though:

1.43pm GMT

IG Index is predicting a gentle start to trading on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones industrial average tipped to creep a little higher.

1.31pm GMT

Another (small) boost for the Irish economy as it prepares to exits its bailout programme next month, reports Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald:

Two hi-tech Indian companies have announced they are creating 75 jobs between them in Dublin while 50 posts are also being established in the Irish capital by loyalty card company Value Nation.
Synowledge has announced 35 positions as it establishes an international headquarters in Dublin while Aditi Technologies is setting up a European Services and Business Development Centre with the creation of 40 jobs.

The move further enhances Dublin's reputation as the bridgehead for international hi-tech companies into the European market, says Henry. However....

There was a reminder over the weekend of the reasons behind Ireland's economic crash particularly its out-of control building and property speculation bubble during the Celtic Tiger years. It was reported that up to 40 so called 'ghost estates' will be demolished under the orders of Labour Minister for Housing Jan O'Sullivan. 
The empty estates which were built during the construction boom have come to symbolise the collapse of the Celtic Tiger economy.

1.19pm GMT

This morning's talks between the Greek government and the Troika (see 12.08pm) appear to have ended. A finance ministry spokesman is telling reporters in Athens that "all issues" were discussed, and that the government plans to present its 2014 budget to parliament on Thursday.

1.00pm GMT

DAX hits new record high as European markets climb

Back in the stock markets, the German DAX has hit a new record high as European markets follow the overnight rally on the Hong Kong and Shanghai markets with their own rises. 

Investors continue to give China's new economic reforms a thumbs-up (see opening post for details). They are also cheered by the confident monthly report from the Bundesbank (see here) and the prospect of continued stimulus measures from the US central bank (yes, again...)

It all adds up to another day of rising stock markets, as traders remain unconcerned that growth in the eurozone ground to a near-standstill in the last quarter.

The DAX has risen 68 points, or 0.75%, to an all-time of 9,236, led by utilities giants RWE and E.ON (both benefitting from an upbeat analyst note from Exane BNP Paribas).

Other European markets are also higher today, with financial shares leading the rally.

In London, the FTSE 100 has gained 32 points of 0.5% - lead by Aberdeen Asset management (up 15% after announcing strong results and the purchase of Scottish Widows this morning). Standard Chartered, RBS and Lloyds are up between 1.5% and 2%.

Burberry shares are also in the FTSE risers, gaining 1.2%. It should benefit of Beijing can succeed in its goal of stimulating domestic consumption.

As Alastair Winter of Daniel Stewart put it:

They [China] are very serious about the switch to consumption... The Burberries of this world are laughing.

Italy's FTSE MIB is the best performing index - up over 2%, led by its banks. Spain's IBEX is up 1.3% 

This means world stock markets are a new five year high, having hit their highest level since January 2008 at the start of trading (as measured by MSCI's daily snapshot of equities at 8am).

Here's the situation across Europe (green = up today)

12.08pm GMT

Troika talks resume in Athens

It's the start of a busy week in Greece, as finance minister Yannis Stournaras sits down for another session of talks with the country's lenders.

Relations between the Athens government and officials from the IMF/EC and ECB are increasingly strained, insiders say, with no agreement over how to address the fiscal gap in Greece's 2014 financial plans. That shortfall is currently seen at around €1.5bn, Kathimerini reckons, and it's not clear how it will be fixed.

Greece's government insists that it cannot implement further austerity, while the Troika aren't convinced that the savings can come from structural reforms. Last Thursday, the eurogroup (eurozone finance ministers) urged the Greeks to make more progress.

As Athens correspondent Helena Smith explains:

Finance minister Stournaras will today try to persuade visiting mission chiefs that next year's budget black hole can be fixed by applying structural reforms.

The troika want more wage and pension cuts which many feel will simply tip Greeks over the edge given that they have lost 40% of their disposal income since start of crisis. 

Greece's government is due to present its 2014 budget to parliament on Thursday, while prime minister Samaras is visiting Germany on Friday to meet Angela Merkel.

Analysts at Merrill Lynch are speculating that Greece's lenders may have to accept another haircut:

11.57am GMT

On that Bundesbank report....

11.37am GMT

Bundesbank: German recovery gathering strength

Confident stuff from the Bundesbank this morning. In its monthly report, the German central bank reported that:

There's a good chance that the economic upturn in Germany will be further cemented in the coming months.

It cited increased domestic demand, and an improved global economy.

On monetary issues, the Bundesbank said that ECB's current expansive policy was 'justified', but cautioned that there could be dangers to financial stability in the medium to long-term.

Interesting, given its boss Jens Weidmann wasn't in favour of this month's ECB rate cut.

More on Reuters.

Updated at 12.25pm GMT

11.11am GMT

Here's the key graph from the IFS's report into an Independent Scotland: 

Updated at 11.12am GMT

11.08am GMT

Independent Scotland faces 'tough choices'

The respected thinktank, the Institute for Fiscal Studies has been looking at the public finance aspects of an independent Scotland (writes Katie Allen)

It believes that if Scotland were to break away it would need a significant cut in spending or increase in taxes, over and above that already announced by the UK government, in order to put its long-term public finances onto a sustainable footing.

The IFS, perhaps best known for its meticulous dissection of the chancellor’s budgets, says the scale of such fiscal tightening is likely to be greater than that required for the UK as a whole.

The research, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC), suggests that even under the most optimistic scenario, the long-run ‘fiscal gap’ in Scotland would be 1.9% of national income compared to 0.8% of national income for the UK as a whole.

Gemma Tetlow, a programme director at the IFS and an author of the report comments:

An independent Scotland would face even tougher choices than those faced by the UK over the longer term. In 2011–12, higher public spending per person in Scotland was more than matched by higher revenues from activity in the North Sea.

However, over the long-term, revenues from the North Sea will probably decline and official population projections suggest that the average age of the Scottish population will increase more rapidly than for the UK as a whole, putting greater upward pressure on many areas of public spending. As a result, to ensure long-run fiscal sustainability, an independent Scotland would need to cut public spending and/or increase other tax revenues more than would be required across the UK as a whole.Read the full report here:

Updated at 11.08am GMT

10.52am GMT

BoE Survey: Risk of 'high-impact' financial event has dropped

Financial market players in the UK generally feel more optimistic about the economic outlook, according to the half-yearly Systemic Risk Survey just released by the Bank of England.

But their fears around the current low interest rate environment as well as rising housing prices have increased.

Economics reporter Katie Allen has the details:

The perceived probability of a high-impact event in the UK financial system over both the short and medium term continued to fall over recent months and is at the lowest since the survey began at the onset of the financial crisis in 2008.

According to the BoE’s poll of risk managers at hedge funds, banks, insurers and other financial institutions, 55% (up 5 percentage points from May) now consider the probability low or very low over the next year, 16% (up 3 percentage points) between one and three years ahead.

Confidence in the UK financial system has also risen with 18% (up 1 percentage point) completely confident or very confident in the stability of the UK financial system as a whole over the next three years, 78% fairly confident (up 8 percentage points) and only 4% not very confident (down 9 percentage points).

And here are more key quotes from the report (online here):

Perceptions of the two main risks to the UK financial system remain sovereign risk and the risk of an economic downturn, although citations of both have fallen.

Concerns over sovereign risk continue to focus on Europe, but unsurprisingly given the uncertainty surrounding US debt ceiling negotiations that prevailed during the survey period, there was a sharp increase in concerns around US sovereign risk.

For the second survey in succession, risk surrounding the low interest rate environment was the fastest growing, with 43% of respondents citing it, up 17 percentage points since May 2013. Over half of the responses emphasised risks around low rates, with the remainder referring to risks associated with a snapback in those low rates to more normal levels. Perceived risk around property prices also rose, being mentioned by 36% of respondents, up 11 percentage points since the previous survey. Concerns were concentrated almost exclusively on the residential market, where responses focused on the risk of a house price correction.

[end]

10.27am GMT

There is one piece of good news for Madrid residents - street cleaners voted yesterday to end a strike which began two weeks ago.

Union and management reached an agreement after lengthy overnight negotiations, which began on Saturday after local government workers began dealing with the piles of rubbish that littered the Spanish capital.

The strike began after the private firms who run cleaning and rubbish collection on Madrid's streets announced more than 1,100 job cuts and threatened to cut the pay of the remaining 5,000 employees.

The deal hammered out over the weekend will save jobs, but mean wage cuts. as CNN reports:

In the predawn deal on Sunday, management agreed not to lay off anyone; but in exchange, the workers will be subject to 1.5-month furloughs each year through 2017, equivalent to about a 9% salary reduction, Aguilar said.

"Under the circumstances, we achieved something good," said Francisco Aguilar [a local leader of the CGT union] on the unions' insistence on saving jobs in the economic crisis in Spain, which has a 25.9% jobless rate and 5.9 million people out of work. The youth jobless rate is 54%.

Tourism officers and businesses had warned that the sight of refuse heaped up across the capital was harming Spain's image, as well as being most unpleasant for people on the streets.

A mea culpa from Goldman Sachs may raise spirits, though.

Stephen writes:

Despite a series of upbeat predictions from the Spanish government and a range of financial institutions, people on the ground see no reasons to be cheerful about the Spanish economic recovery.

In a poll published in El Mundo newspaper, 88% of Spaniards say they have not personally witnessed any improvement, while 75% don’t believe the country is exiting the crisis. Even supporters of the ruling Partido Pouplar show little sign of optimism, with 79% saying they have yet to spot any green shoots.

Altogether, a mere 15% of those polled believe the recovery is at hand. To complicate matters further for the cash-strapped government, 69% of Spaniards are calling for tax cuts.

Goldman Sachs is the latest financial institution to upgrade its forecasts for the Spanish economy. In a report titled “Mea culpa or mea maxima culpa?” the bank admits there were errors in its previous assessment of the prospects for a Spanish recovery.

In October 2012 it said that “the worst is still to come for Spain.”

10.08am GMT

Yves Mersch, Luxembourg central bank governor and member of the ECB's governing council, has declared that eurozone's economic woes are easing - despite growth slipping to just 0.1% in the last quarter.

Reuters reports:

The worst of the euro zone's economic troubles are behind it and the bloc can look to the future with confidence, European Central Bank Executive Board member Yves Mersch said on Monday.

"I think we should look to the future with confidence. I think there are reasons for that. I think the worst is behind us," Mersch said in a speech at the Euro Finance conference in Frankfurt.

The Italian PM's speech (see last post) didn't impress Wolf Piccoli, managing director at Teneo Intelligence:

On the political situation, economist Meg Greene reckons that Matteo Renzi, the charismatic centre-left mayor of Florence (and a key player in Enrico Letta's own Democratic Party) poses a greater threat to Letta's fortunes than those squabbling right-wingers.

There's no dispute over Letta's warning about youth unemployment, though:

9.47am GMT

Enrico Letta promises privatisation progress

Italian prime minister Enrico Letta has announced that his government will announce details of its new privatisation plans later this week.

Speaking at a conference in Rome this morning, organised by the FT, Letta said he was confident that state asset sales would help Italy cut its deficit in 2014. He said next year would be a crucial time for reforms in Italy, whose economy has shrunk for the last nine quarters.

Letta also acknowledged that Italy's young have suffered badly from the economic turmoil of recent years, calling its youth unemployment "a nightmare".

Italian journalist Fab Goria has the key quotes:

Letta also declared that his government was made more stable by the latest developments in Italian centre-right politics.

Over the weekend, deputy PM Angelino Alfano announced that a group of right-leading MPs would break away from Silvio Berlusconi and form a new Centre-Right party. Alfano pledged to support Letta, which means the coalition should be secure even if/when Berlusconi leads his remaining supports into opposition.

Updated at 10.00am GMT

9.25am GMT

Britain's love affair with Prosecco continues apace, with Majestic Wine reporting a 39% jump in demand for Italian fizz in the six months to 30 September.

Total like-for-like sales at Majestic were down 0.4% year-on-year, while profits are up 4.2% (2012 sales were helped by the Golden Jubilee, apparently). Prosecco sales are leading the way.

Tough economic times must be driving some shoppers to more affordable bottles - you can get two bottles of Prosecco from Majestic at just £6.99 each. Not that it's not rather glugable in its own right, of course (so I've heard, anyway...)

At the top-end of the market, sales of bottles costing £20 or more rose by 15.6%.

CEO Steve Lewis is upbeat, saying:

These results show we continue to make steady progress towards our strategic growth objectives and we are very well prepared for the peak Christmas trading period.

Updated at 12.31pm GMT

9.04am GMT

In London, Aberdeen Asset Management shares are up 13% (leading the FTSE 100 risers), after agreeing a deal to buy Scottish Widows from Lloyds Banking Group. A 39% jump in pre-tax profits helped too. 

8.59am GMT

European stock markets remain near their highest levels in five years this morning. Aerospace group EADS shares are up 3% after announcing new deals at the Dubai air show, while Switzerland's Sonova jumped 6.6% after raising its profit guidance.

8.46am GMT

Liv Garfield leaves BT for Severn Trent

In the UK corporate world, BT has lost perhaps its brightest rising star - Liv Garfield.

Garfield, who championed and oversaw the rollout of BT's new high-speed fibre optic network as boss of BT Openreach, is leaving to join Severn Trent as CEO.

Garfield's rather well respected in the City, having reached the top at a rather young age (she's 38). She came 10th in Fortune Magazine's "40 under 40", with this citation:

As strategy director for BT, Garfield made the $4 billion case for building out fibre broadband to 19 million UK homes. Now, as CEO of BT’s infrastructure division, she’s doing it, managing more than 20,000 engineers.

Recently named to the board of British megachain Tesco, she’s said to be a contender one day for BT’s top spot.

Instead, she's going to take over at Severn Trent in early 2014, adding to the ranks of female bosses at Footsie firms (alongside EasyJet's Carolyn McCall and Imperial Tobacco's Alison Cooper, as Burberry's Angela Ahrendts is heading to Apple).

Here's a nice interview with Garfield by The Press of York, in which she says her dream job would be to manage Everton Football Club (still time, Liv, still time....) Her biggest mistake? Buying a sports car before finding she was pregnant (she's got two sons).

And here's some early reaction:

Updated at 8.49am GMT

8.18am GMT

World markets at highest since January 2008

The Chinese stock market rally has driven world markets to their highest levels since early 2008, Reuters reports:

18-Nov-2013 08:06 - MSCI'S WORLD SHARE INDEX HITS HIGHEST LEVEL SINCE JAN 2008 AFTER JUMP IN CHINA SHARES, REACHES 401.12 

That's despite a calm start in Europe, where the FTSE 100 index is up a measly 1 point.

Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, says European markets are trading:

around break-even despite the China & Hong Kong rally on wide-ranging reforms including the easing of the one-child policy, more private investment instate-controlled industries and more room for market forces in terms of pricing.

Updated at 8.18am GMT

7.56am GMT

Chinese markets boosted by Plenum reforms

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

China's stock markets have posted a decent rally today, as investors hailed details of the Beijing government's latest reform agenda.

China's economic and social reforms sent shares on the Shanghai Composite index up by 2.8%. Shares have romped ahead in Hong Kong too, where the Hang Seng is up almost 3% in late trading. 

Details of the measures  were released on Friday. Aanalysts saying President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang's plans are the boldest in decades, and will help China shift to a more western-style economy more reliant on services and domestic consumption.

The reforms include: handing more control over the pricing of water, electricity and natural resources to the markets; liberalising the interest rate and currency regime; shaking up the welfare system to encourage labour movement; revamping the rules for stock market flotations; and relaxing the state's control on farmland. (check out CNBC's "China’s economic reforms: What you need to know" for more)

Stan Shamu of IG says the markets like the look it:

After a slow start, markets have picked up momentum in Asia with China leading the way. China has been a focal point today as details from its Third Plenum have finally emerged.

The four biggest changes are to the one child policy, the hukou policy (housing registration legislation), private investment and fiscal and tax laws. Different reforms have impacted different industries and the overall reaction today has turned out to be positive, with a sense of optimism that these reforms are for the better.

The decision to relax China's controversial one-child policy also boosted shares, as the WSJ explains:

Companies that make products for babies also shot higher after Beijing said that it would be relax the one-child policy that has been in place for more than three decades.

Hengan International Group Co, a nappy producer, was the best performer on the Hang Seng Index with its 5.8% gain. Infant formula producer Biostime International Holdings rose 3.4%.

Encouraging stuff. However, European investors aren't expected to share the rally - with the main markets expected to open pretty flat.

Otherwise, it looks like a pretty quiet day... but I'll be tracking all action (such as we can find!) through the day.

Marks says he believes US growth will be a little faster in 2014 than this year, but it don't reach levels where people actually feel wealthier. Here's a graph showing how the Dow Jones industrial average has risen by around a quarter in the last 12 months: It's been a pretty steady rise, apart from a couple of wobbles since the summer. Boeing is the biggest riser on the Dow Jones index, up almost 3% after it reported a $76bn deal to sell 150 777 mini-jumbos to the Emirates airline. If it feels like the US stock markets are hitting new record highs every few days, then you're right. Scarlet Fu, chief markets correspondent for Bloomberg Television, reports that one in every four trading days in 2013 has seen a new record high on the Dow Jones or the S&P 500 (or both). Aanalysts saying President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang's plans are the boldest in decades, and will help China shift to a more western-style economy more reliant on services and domestic consumption. The four biggest changes are to the one child policy, the hukou policy (housing registration legislation), private investment and fiscal and tax laws. Different reforms have impacted different industries and the overall reaction today has turned out to be positive, with a sense of optimism that these reforms are for the better. webTitle: Wave goodbye to 'golden hellos', UK pension funds urge

fields.standfirst: Pensions body says executives should not receive a signing-on bonus that covers shares built up at previous employer
fields.body:
Britain's pension funds have called for an end to "golden hellos" as part of a wider clampdown on company pay and governance.

The National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) said companies should not pay executives a signing-on bonus that covers shares built up at their previous employer because shares are often awarded to executives to secure their loyalty.

The pensions body, whose members oversee £900bn of investments, said shareholders should vote against such pay arrangements unless the company had a good justification for them.

From the start of last month shareholder votes against executive pay became binding – they had previously been advisory and often ignored.

But the practice of paying golden hellos caused uproar in 2011 when Trevor Matthews joined Aviva from Friends Life. He received a £2.2m package which included a £470,000 cash payment for forfeiting unvested shares and his 2011 bonus from his previous employer.

The arrangement inflicted a defeat on Aviva at its annual meeting, contributed to the departure of chief executive Andrew Moss and helped spark the so-called shareholder spring of investor rebellions last year.

Joanne Segars, NAPF's chief executive, said: "We are more strongly encouraging companies to identify and engage with their long-term investors, rather than those on their register who are more interested in short-term trading. We expect remuneration committees to set rewards which drive long-term strategic success and seek to reward performance over the longer-term."

In its new guidelines, NAPF called on companies to pay top management in line with the interests of long-term shareholders instead of investors looking to make a quick return.

The pension group said executives should hold shares worth at least twice their salary to make sure their interests corresponded with those of shareholders. It also called for simpler long-term share awards and an end to grafting new schemes on top of existing plans.

NAPF's other major intervention was on the independence of auditors from company management. Shareholder revolts against auditors at annual meetings have increased, either because auditors have been in place too long or because fees for more lucrative work such as management consultancy exceeded the cost of the audit.

NAPF said for the first time that shareholders should vote against the audit fees or the chair of the audit committee if the company paid its auditing firm more for other services, such as consultancy, than for its audit – or if it paid it more than £500,000 in non-audit fees two years running.

At Pennon's annual meeting in August, 49% of votes withheld support for the board to set fees for PwC. The water company paid PwC £721,000 in audit fees but more than double that for other services, including £880,000 for corporate finance work.

The pension investors' intervention came after a report showed executive pay rose 14% last year and accused companies of making ever-larger share-based awards to deflect public scrutiny.

While basic salaries rose 4.1% and annual bonuses fell by 8.8%, the total pay package for an average FTSE 100 director rose sharply through a 58% surge in the value of share-based long-term incentive plan (LTIP) awards being cashed in, from £764,462 to £1,208,940, according to Income Data Services.

webTitle: Aveva drops 7.5% as software group suffers contract problems

fields.standfirst: Group's enterprise solutions division disappoints after customer project difficulties
fields.body:
Aveva, whose software is used to design power plants, shipping and energy facilities, has dropped sharply following a disappointing update.

The company's shares have lost 195p or 7.5% to £23.71, making it the biggest faller in the mid-cap index. The headline figures showed an 11% increase in half year revenues to £108.5m and a 6% rise in profits to £27.3m, but within that, its enterprise solutions division showed a slower than expected 5% revenue rise.

The company blamed a Latin American shipyard customer running into serious financial difficulties, and a major oil and gas group abandoning an information management project. Aveva added that the market was still evolving so sales cycles were hard to predict. Analyst George O'Connor at Panmure Gordon issued a hold note, saying:

In the wake of these results we have elected to increase revenue and reduce pretax profit. Salient factors include (1) a poorer first half than we expected from enterprise where we now factor in a full year loss; (2) better than expected on engineering and design; (3) stronger than expected cash generation. Ahead of the results, we had anticipated full year revenue of £240.7m, pretax profit of £81.9m and earnings per share of 86.6p with the divisions enterprise £203.3m and engineering and design £37.4m. We now revise these to revenue £242.1m, profit £76.9m and earnings 83.7p, with the divisions, enterprise £37.4m and engineering and design £206.8m.

Julian Yates at Investec reduced his recommendation from buy to hold:

The headline numbers were in-line with our estimates but the focus will be on the divisional performance. While the core engineering and design performed well, slightly ahead of our estimates, enterprise solutions was below expectations. Its outlook has been revised down to flat 2014 sales due to longer sales cycles and customer specific issues. A planned cost reduction in the second half of 2014 in enterprise and the modest engineering outperformance should mean group 2014 profit expectations are still met. With no near term catalyst to justify a higher target price, we move to hold.

webTitle: Spanish taxpayers pay price as king goes from have-yacht to have-not

fields.standfirst: It was meant to showcase his modesty – but King Juan Carlos's renunciation of his yacht, Fortuna, is going to cost
fields.body:
King Juan Carlos' gesture of frugality earlier this year when he renounced his yacht has backfired after a court ruled that the crew were owed €1.2m (£1m) in payment for illegal dismissal.

The money will come from the Patrimonio Nacional, Spain's equivalent of the civil list. In short, the taxpayer will foot the bill.

The 41.6-metre (137ft) yacht, called Fortuna, was moored in Mallorca and cost €21m. It was a gift from a consortium of businessmen in the Balearic islands, each of whom contributed €600,000.

Now that the king has renounced the yacht, they plan to recoup some of their outlay by selling the vessel.

Fortuna was used mainly for photo opportunities of the king relaxing on board with his family and visiting dignitaries; Prince Charles and Diana, Princess of Wales, were guests in 1990.

During court proceedings brought by the crew, who claim wrongful dismissal, it emerged that the captain had a salary of €138,000, almost double that of the prime minister. webTitle: Liv Garfield: fast-rising corporate star

fields.standfirst: Profile: At 38, the fast-talking Yorkshirewoman will become one of the FTSE 100's youngest ever chief executives when she takes over at water company Severn Trent
fields.body:
Liv Garfield is at the top of her game. Tasked with the £2.5bn roll-out of super-fast fibre broadband as BT's boss of Openreach, she was tipped as a future leader of the telecoms giant.

But after 12 years at the company and at the age of just 38, she will leave to become one of the FTSE 100's youngest ever chief executives when she joins water company Severn Trent in spring next year.

Her appointment will catapult her into an exclusive club, as one of just four female chief executives in the FTSE 100. That club will become more exclusive still when Angela Ahrendts departs Burberry for Apple in the middle of next year.

Garfield's appointment has confirmed what many suspected: she is a high flyer destined for the top in the corporate world.

The fast-talking Yorkshire-born Cambridge graduate was recently ranked 10th in Fortune magazine's annual 40 under 40 list, making her the only Brit to feature in the top 10 of the exclusive league table of the world's fastest rising young corporate stars.

Her abilities had already been recognised by Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, which appointed her a non-executive director in April.

Meanwhile her achievements at BT speak for themselves. In a previous role as the group's strategy director, she was instrumental in building the business case for BT's commercial fibre investment which she has taken from concept through to delivery. The roll-out of the programme under her leadership is on track to be completed in spring next year, around 18 months ahead of schedule.

"Fibre is my absolute baby. I came up with the idea that we should do it and took it to the board," she said in an interview last year.

"Now I have the responsibility for actually making it happen. It's just brilliant to be able to take it from an idea to the physical engineering of it."

Since taking on the top role at Openreach in April 2011, the availability of fibre broadband has risen from around 4m premises to more than 17m. Over the same period the number of customers adopting fibre has increased from just over 100,000 to more than 2m today.

Garfield is decisive, no doubt a requisite characteristic for the chief executive designate of one of Britain's biggest companies. She has a self-confessed low tolerance threshold for faffers, and despite juggling the demands of a young family and a demanding career, the mother of two sons prides herself on her time keeping.

"I'm organised. I'm a working mum of two kids, I've got a busy day job and I'll have a busy non-exec job, too," she told the Telegraph in April.

Garfield grew up in the North Yorkshire town of Harrogate but she is a life-long Everton fan. Her grandfather was one of the of the football clubs' groundsmen at Goodison Park, and she regularly attended home matches.

Before joining BT she worked for Accenture as a consultant in the communications and hi-tech market division.

Openreach has the most employees of all BT's divisions with 30,000 staff, 22,000 of whom are engineers, and the business has a £5bn turnover.

BT has launched a search for someone to succeed Garfield, but hers will be big boots to fill.
